title: Two Gentlemen of Verona from Mr. William Shakespeares comedies, histories, & tragedies. Published according to the true originall copies.

characters.name: Duke of Milan, father to Silvia
Eglamour, agent for Silvia in her escape
Speed, a clownish servant to Valentine
Thurio, a foolish rival to Valentine

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: CEase to perswade, my louing {% italic: Protheus %}:

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: Home‑keeping youth, haue euer homely wits,

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: Wer't not affection chaines thy tender dayes

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: To the sweet glaunces of thy honour'd Loue,

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: I rather would entreat thy company,

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: To see the wonders of the world abroad,

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: Then (liuing dully sluggardiz'd at home)

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: Weare out thy youth with shapelesse idlenesse,

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: But since thou lou'st; loue still, and thriue therein,

lines.speaker: Valentine.
lines.text: Euen as I would, when I to loue begin.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet {% italic: Valentine %}, adew,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Thinke on thy {% italic: Protheus %}, when thou (hap'ly) seest

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Some rare note‑worthy object in thy trauaile.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Wish me partaker in thy happinesse,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: When thou do'st meet good hap; and in thy danger,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: (If euer danger doe enuiron thee)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Commend thy grieuance to my holy prayers,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For I will be thy beades‑man, {% italic: Vaelentine %}.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: And on a loue‑booke pray for my successe?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Vpon some booke I loue, I'le pray for thee.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: That's on some shallow Storie of deepe loue,

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: How yong {% italic: Leander %} crost the {% italic: Hellespont %}.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That's a deepe Storie, of a deeper loue;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For he was more then ouer‑shooes in loue.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: 'Tis true; for you are ouer‑bootes in loue,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And yet you neuer swom the {% italic: Hellespont %}.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Ouer the Bootes? nay giue me not the Boots.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: No, I will not; for it boots thee not.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: To be in loue; where scorne is bought with ( grones:

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Coy looks, with hart‑sore sighes: one fading moments mirth,

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: With twenty watchfull, weary, tedious nights;

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: If hap'ly won, perhaps a haplesse gaine;

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: If lost, why then a grieuous labour won;

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: How euer: but a folly bought with wit,

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Or else a wit, by folly vanquished.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: So, by your circumstance, you call me foole.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: So, by your circumstance, I feare you'll proue.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: 'Tis loue you cauill at, I am not Loue.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Loue is your master, for he masters you;

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And he that is so yoked by a foole,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Me thinkes should not be chronicled for wise.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Yet Writers say; as in the sweetest Bud,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: The eating Canker dwels; so eating Loue

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And Writers say; as the most forward Bud

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Is eaten by the Canker ere it blow,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Euen so by Loue, the yong, and tender wit

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the Bud,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Loosing his verdure, euen in the prime,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And all the faire effects of future hopes.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: But wherefore waste I time to counsaile thee

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: That art a votary to fond desire?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Once more adieu: my Father at the Road

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Expects my comming, there to see me ship'd.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And thither will I bring thee, {% italic: Valentine %}.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Sweet {% italic: Protheus %}, no: Now let vs take our leaue:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: To {% italic: Millaine %} let me heare from thee by Letters

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Of thy successe in loue; and what newes else

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Betideth here in absence of thy Friend:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And I likewise will visite thee with mine.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: All happinesse bechance to thee in {% italic: Millaine %}.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: As much to you at home: and so farewell.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: He after Honour hunts, I after Loue;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: He leaues his friends, to dignifie them more;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I loue my selfe, my friends, and all for loue;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Thou, {% italic: Iulia %} thou hast metamorphis'd me:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Made me neglect my Studies, loose my time;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Warre with good counsaile; set the world at nought;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Made Wit with musing, weake; hart sick with thought.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Protheus %}: 'saue you: saw you my Master?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But now he parted hence to embarque for {% italic: Millain %}.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Twenty to one then, he is ship'd already,

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: And I haue plaid the Sheepe in loosing him.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Indeed a Sheep doth very often stray,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And if the Shepheard be awhile away.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: You conclude that my Master is a Shepheard then,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I doe.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Why then my hornes are his hornes, whether I

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: A silly answere, and fitting well a Sheepe.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: This proues me still a Sheepe.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: True: and thy Master a Shepheard.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: It shall goe hard but ile proue it by another.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: The Shepheard seekes the Sheepe, and not the

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: The Sheepe for fodder follow the Shepheard,

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Such another proofe will make me cry baâ.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But do'st thou heare: gau'st thou my Letter {% italic: Iulia %}?

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: I Sir: I (a lost‑Mutton) gaue your Letter to her

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Here's too small a Pasture for such store of

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: If the ground be ouer‑charg'd, you were best

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Nay, in that you are astray: 'twere best pound

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Nay Sir, lesse then a pound shall serue me for car­rying

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: You mistake; I meane the pound, a Pinfold.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: From a pound to a pin? fold it ouer and ouer,

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to your louer

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But what said she?

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: I.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Nod‑I, Why that's noddy.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: You mistooke Sir: I say she did nod;

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: And you aske me if she did nod, and I say I.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And that set together is noddy.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Now you haue taken the paines to set it toge­

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: No, no, you shall haue it for bearing the letter.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Well, I perceiue I must be faine to bear with you.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Why Sir, how doe you beare with me?

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Marry Sir, the letter very orderly,

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Hauing nothing but the word noddy for my paines.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Beshrew me, but you haue a quicke wit.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: And yet it cannot ouer‑take your slow purse.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Come, come, open the matter in briefe; what

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Open your purse, that the money, and the matter

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Well Sir: here is for your paines: what said she?

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Truely Sir, I thinke you'll hardly win her.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Why? could'st thou perceiue so much from her?

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Sir, I could perceiue nothing at all from her;

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: No, not so much as a ducket for deliuering your letter:

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: And being so hard to me, that brought your minde;

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: I feare she'll proue as hard to you in telling your minde.

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: Giue her no token but stones, for she's as hard as steele.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: What said she, nothing?

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: No, not so much as take this for thy pains:

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: To testifie your bounty, I thank you, you haue cestern'd ( me;

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: In requital whereof, henceforth, carry your letters your

lines.speaker: Sp.
lines.text: selfe; And so, Sir, I'le commend you to my Master.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Go, go, be gone, to saue your Ship from wrack,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Which cannot perish hauing thee aboarde,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Being destin'd to a drier death on shore;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I must goe send some better Messenger,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I feare my {% italic: Iulia %} would not daigne my lines,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Receiuing them from such a worthlesse post.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: But say {% italic: Luceita %} (now we are alone)

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Would'st thou then counsaile me to fall in loue?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: I Madam, so you stumble not vnheedfully.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Of all the faire resort of Gentlemen,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: That euery day with par'le encounter me,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: In thy opinion which is worthiest loue?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Please you repeat their names; ile shew my minde,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: According to my shallow simple skill.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: What thinkst thou of the faire sir {% italic: Eglamoure %}?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: As of a Knight, well‑spoken, neat, and fine;

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: But were I you, he neuer should be mine.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: What think'st thou of the rich {% italic: Mercatio %}?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so, so.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: What think'st thou of the gentle {% italic: Protheus %}?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Lord, Lord: to see what folly raignes in vs.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: How now? what meanes this passion at his name?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Pardon deare Madam; 'tis a passing shame

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: That I (vnworthy body as I am)

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Should censure thus on louely Gentlemen.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Why not on {% italic: Protheus %}, as of all the rest?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Then thus: of many good, I thinke him best.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Your reason?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I haue no other but a womans reason:

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I thinke him so, because I thinke him so.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And would'st thou haue me cast my loue on him?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I: if you thought your loue not cast away.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Why he, of all the rest, hath neuer mou'd me.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Yet he, of all the rest, I thinke best loues ye.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: His little speaking, shewes his loue but small.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Fire that's closest kept, burnes most of all.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: They doe not loue, that doe not shew their loue.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Oh, they loue least, that let men know their loue.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: I would I knew his minde.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Peruse this paper Madam.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To {% italic: Iulia %}: Say, from whom?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: That the Contents will shew.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Say, say: who gaue it thee?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Valentines %} page: & sent I think from {% italic: Protheus %};

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: He would haue giuen it you, but I being in the way,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Did in your name receiue it: pardon the fault I pray.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Now (by my modesty) a goodly Broker:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To whisper, and conspire against my youth?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Now trust me, 'tis an office of great worth,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And you an officer fit for the place:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: There: take the paper: see it be return'd,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Or else returne no more into my sight.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: To plead for loue, deserues more fee, then hate.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Will ye be gon?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: That you may ruminate.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And yet I would I had ore‑look'd the Letter;

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: It were a shame to call her backe againe,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And pray her to a fault, for which I chid her.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: What 'foole is she, that knowes I am a Maid,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And would not force the letter to my view?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Since Maides, in modesty, say no to that,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Which they would haue the profferer construe, I.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Fie, fie: how way‑ward is this foolish loue;

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: That (like a testie Babe) will scratch the Nurse,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And presently, all humbled kisse the Rod?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: How churlishly, I chid {% italic: Lucetta %} hence,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: When willingly, I would haue had her here?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: How angerly I taught my brow to frowne,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: When inward ioy enforc'd my heart to smile?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: My pennance is, to call {% italic: Lucetta %} backe

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And aske remission, for my folly past.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: What hoe: {% italic: Lucetta %}.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: What would your Ladiship?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Is't neere dinner time?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I would it were,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: That you might kill your stomacke on your meat,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: And not vpon your Maid.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: What is't that you

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Tooke vp so gingerly?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Nothing.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Why didst thou stoope then?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: To take a paper vp, that I let fall.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And is that paper nothing?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Nothing concerning me.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Then let it lye, for those that it concernes.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Madam, it will not lye where it concernes,

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Vnlesse it haue a false Interpreter.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Some loue of yours, hath writ to you in Rime.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: That I might sing it (Madam) to a tune:

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Giue me a Note, your Ladiship can set

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: As little by such toyes, as may be possible:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Best sing it to the tune of {% italic: Light O, Loue %}.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: It is too heauy for so light a tune.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Heauy? belike it hath some burden then?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I: and melodious were it, would you sing it,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: And why not you?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I cannot reach so high.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Let's see your Song:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: How now Minion?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Keepe tune there still; so you will sing it out:

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: And yet me thinkes I do not like this tune.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: You doe not?

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: No (Madam) tis too sharpe.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: You (Minion) are too saucie.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Nay, now you are too flat;

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: And marre the concord, with too harsh a descant:

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: There wanteth but a Meane to fill your Song.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: The meane is dround with you vnruly base.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Indeede I bid the base for {% italic: Protheus %}.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me;

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Here is a coile with protestation:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Goe, get you gone: and let the papers lye:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: You would be fingring them, to anger me.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: She makes it strange, but she would be best pleas'd

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: To be so angred with another Letter.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Nay, would I were so angred with the same:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Oh hatefull hands, to teare such louing words;

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Iniurious Waspes, to feede on such sweet hony,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: And kill the Bees that yeelde it, with your stings:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Ile kisse each seuerall paper, for amends:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Looke, here is writ, kinde {% italic: Iulia %}: vnkinde {% italic: Iulia %},

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: As in reuenge of thy ingratitude,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: I throw thy name against the bruzing-stones,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Trampling contemptuously on thy disdaine.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: And here is writ, {% italic: Loue wounded Protheus %}.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Poor wounded name: my bosome, as a bed,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly heal'd;

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: And thus I search it with a soueraigne kisse.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: But twice, or thrice, was {% italic: Protheus %} written downe:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Be calme (good winde) blow not a word away,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Till I haue found each letter, in the Letter,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Except mine own name: That, some whirle‑winde beare

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Vnto a ragged, fearefull, hanging Rocke,

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: And throw it thence into the raging Sea.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Loe, here in one line is his name twice writ:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Poore forlorne Protheus, passionate Protheus:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: {% italic: To the sweet Iulia %}: that ile teare away:

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: And yet I will not, sith so prettily

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: He couples it, to his complaining Names;

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Thus will I fold them, one vpon another;

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Now kisse, embrace, contend, doe what you will.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Madam: dinner is ready: and your father staies.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Well, let vs goe.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: What, shall these papers lye, like Tel‑tales here?

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: If you respect them; best to take them vp.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Nay, I was taken vp, for laying them downe.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: Yet here they shall not lye, for catching cold.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: I see you haue a months minde to them.

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I (Madam) you may say what sights you see;

lines.speaker: Lu.
lines.text: I see things too, although you iudge I winke.

lines.speaker: Iu.
lines.text: Come, come, wilt please you goe.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Tell me {% italic: Panthino %}, what sad talke was that,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Wherewith my brother held you in the Cloyster?

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: 'Twas of his Nephew {% italic: Protheus %}, your Sonne.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Why? what of him?

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: He wondred that your Lordship

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Would suffer him, to spend his youth at home,

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: While other men, of slender reputation

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Put forth their Sonnes, to seeke preferment out.

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Some to the warres, to try their fortune there;

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Some, to discouer Islands farre away:

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Some, to the studious Vniuersities;

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I knew him as my selfe: for from our Infancie

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: We haue conuerst and spent our howres together,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And though my selfe haue beene an idle Trewant,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Omitting the sweet benefit of time

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: To cloath mine age with Angel‑like perfection:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Yet hath Sir {% italic: Protheus %} (for that's his name)

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Made vse, and faire aduantage of his daies:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: His yeares but yong, but his experience old:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: His head vn‑mellowed, but his Iudgement ripe;

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And, in a word (for far behinde his worth

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Comes all the praises that I now bestow.)

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: He is compleat in feature, and in minde,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: With all good grace, to grace a Gentleman.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Beshrew me sir, but if he make this good

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: He is as worthy for an Empresse loue,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: As meet to be an Emperors Councellor:

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Well, Sir: this Gentleman is come to me

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: With Commendation from great Potentates,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And heere he meanes to spend his time a while,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I thinke 'tis no vn‑welcome newes to you.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Should I haue wish'd a thing, it had beene he.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: For {% italic: Ualentine, %} I need not cite him to it,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I will send him hither to you presently.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Welcome him then according to his worth: {% italic: Siluia, %} I speake to you, and you Sir {% italic: Thurio %},

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: This is the Gentleman I told your Ladiship

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Had come along with me, but that his Mistresse

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Did hold his eyes, lockt in her Christall lookes.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Be‑like that now she hath enfranchis'd them

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Vpon some other pawne for fealty.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Nay sure, I thinke she holds them prisoners stil.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Nay then he should be blind, and being blind

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: How could he see his way to seeke out you?

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Why Lady, Loue hath twenty paire of eyes.

lines.speaker: Thur.
lines.text: They say that Loue hath not an eye at all.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: To see such Louers, {% italic: Thurio, %} as your selfe,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Vpon a homely obiect, Loue can winke.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Haue done, haue done: here comes yͤ gentleman.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Welcome, deer {% italic: Protheus %}: Mistris, I beseech you

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Confirme his welcome, with some speciall fauor.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: His worth is warrant for his welcome hether,

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: If this be he you oft haue wish'd to heare from.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Mistris, it is: sweet Lady, entertaine him

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: To be my fellow‑seruant to your Ladiship.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Too low a Mistres for so high a seruant.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Not so, sweet Lady, but too meane a seruant

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To haue a looke of such a worthy a Mistresse.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Leaue off discourse of disabilitie:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Sweet Lady, entertaine him for your Seruant.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: My dutie will I boast of, nothing else.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: And dutie neuer yet did want his meed.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Seruant, you are welcome to a worthlesse Mistresse.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Ile die on him that saies so but your selfe.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: That you are welcome?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That you are worthlesse.

lines.speaker: Thur.
lines.text: Madam, my Lord your father wold speak with ( you.

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: I wait vpon his pleasure: Come Sir {% italic: Thurio %},

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Goe with me: once more, new Seruant welcome;

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: Ile leaue you to confer of home affaires,

lines.speaker: Sil.
lines.text: When you haue done, we looke too heare from you.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Wee'll both attend vpon your Ladiship.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Now tell me: how do al from whence you came?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Your frends are wel, & haue much cōmended.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And how doe yours?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I left them all in health.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: How does your Lady? & how thriues your loue?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: My tales of Loue were wont to weary you,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I know you ioy not in a Loue‑discourse.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I {% italic: Protheus, %} but that life is alter'd now,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I haue done pennance for contemning Loue,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Whose high emperious thoughts haue punish'd me

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: With bitter fasts, with penitentiall grones,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: With nightly teares, and daily hart‑sore sighes,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: For in reuenge of my contempt of loue,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Loue hath chas'd sleepe from my enthralled eyes,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And made them watchers of mine owne hearts sorrow.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: O gentle {% italic: Protheus, %} Loue's a mighty Lord,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And hath so humbled me, as I confesse

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: There is no woe to his correction,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Nor to his Seruice, no such ioy on earth:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Now, no discourse, except it be of loue:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Now can I breake my fast, dine, sup, and sleepe,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Vpon the very naked name of Loue.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Was this the Idoll, that you worship so?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Euen She; and is she not a heauenly Saint?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: No; But she is an earthly Paragon.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Call her diuine.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I will not flatter her.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: O flatter me: for Loue delights in praises.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: When I was sick, you gaue me bitter pils,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And I must minister the like to you.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Then speake the truth by her; if not diuine,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Yet let her be a principalitie,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Soueraigne to all the Creatures on the earth.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Except my Mistresse.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Sweet: except not any,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Fxcept thou wilt except against my Loue.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Haue I not reason to prefer mine owne?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And I will help thee to prefer her to:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Shee shall be dignified with this high honour,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: To beare my Ladies traine, lest the base earth

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Should from her vesture chance to steale a kisse,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And of so great a fauor growing proud,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Disdaine to roote the Sommer‑swelling flowre,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And make rough winter euerlastingly.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Why {% italic: Ualentine, %} what Bragadisme is this?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Pardon me ( {% italic: Protheus %}) all I can is nothing,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: To her, whose worth, make other worthies nothing;

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Shee is alone.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Then let her alone.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Not for the world: why man, she is mine owne,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And I as rich in hauing such a Iewell

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: As twenty Seas, if all their sand were pearle,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: The water, Nectar, and the Rocks pure gold.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Forgiue me that I doe not dreame on thee,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Because thou seest me doate vpon my loue:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: My foolish Riuall that her Father likes

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: (Onely for his possessions are so huge)

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Is gone with her along, and I must after,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: For Loue (thou know'st is full of iealousie.)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But she loues you?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I, and we are betroathd: nay more, our mariage ( howre,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: With all the cunning manner of our flight

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Determin'd of: how I must climbe her window,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: The Ladder made of Cords, and all the means

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Plotted, and 'greed on for my happinesse.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Good {% italic: Protheus %} goe with me to my chamber,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: In these affaires to aid me with thy counsaile.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Goe on before: I shall enquire you forth:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I must vnto the Road, to dis‑embarque

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Some necessaries, that I needs must vse,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And then Ile presently attend you.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Will you make haste?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I will.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Euen as one heate, another heate expels,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Or as one naile, by strength driues out another.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: So the remembrance of my former Loue

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Is by a newer obiect quite forgotten,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: It is mine, or {% italic: Valentines %} praise?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Her true perfection, or my false transgression?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That makes me reasonlesse, to reason thus?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Shee is faire: and so is {% italic: Iulia %} that I loue,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: (That I did loue, for now my loue is thaw'd,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Which like a waxen Image 'gainst a fire

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Beares no impression of the thing it was.)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Me thinkes my zeale to {% italic: Valentine %} is cold,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And that I loue him not as I was wont:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: O, but I loue his Lady too­too much,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And that's the reason I loue him so little.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: How shall I doate on her with more aduice,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That thus without aduice begin to loue her?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: 'Tis but her picture I haue yet beheld,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And that hath dazel'd my reasons light:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But when I looke on her perfections,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: There is no reason, but I shall be blinde.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: If I can checke my erring loue, I will,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: If not, to compasse her Ile vse my skill.

lines.speaker: Speed.
lines.text: {% italic: Launce %}, by mine honesty welcome to {% italic: Padua %}.

lines.speaker: Laun.
lines.text: Forsweare not thy selfe, sweet youth, for I am

lines.speaker: Speed.
lines.text: Come‑on you mad‑cap: Ile to the Ale­house {% italic: Iulia %}?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Marry after they cloas'd in earnest, they parted

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: But shall she marry him?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: How then? shall he marry her?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: No, neither.

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: What, are they broken?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: No; they are both as whole as a fish.

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: Why then, how stands the matter with them?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Marry thus, when it stands well with him, it

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: What an asse art thou, I vnderstand thee not.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: What a blocke art thou, that thou canst not?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: My staffe vnderstands me?

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: What thou saist?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: I, and what I do too: looke thee, Ile but leane,

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: It stands vnder thee indeed.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Why, stand‑vnder: and vnder‑stand is all one.

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: But tell me true, wil't be a match?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Aske my dogge, if he say I, it will: if hee say

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: The conclusion is then, that it will.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Thou shalt neuer get such a secret from me, but

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: 'Tis well that I get it so: but {% italic: Launce, %} how saist

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: I neuer knew him otherwise.

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: Then how?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: A notable Lubber: as thou reportest him to

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: Why, thou whorson Asse, thou mistak'st me,

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Why Foole, I meant not thee, I meant thy

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: I tell thee, my Master is become a hot Louer.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Why, I tell thee, I care not, though hee burne

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as

lines.speaker: Spee.
lines.text: At thy seruice.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To leaue my {% italic: Iulia %}; shall I be forsworne?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To loue faire {% italic: Siluia %}; shall I be forsworne?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworne.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And ev'n that Powre which gaue me first my oath

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Prouokes me to this three‑fold periurie.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Loue bad mee sweare, and Loue bids me for‑sweare;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: O sweet‑suggesting Loue, if thou hast sin'd,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Teach me (thy tempted subiect) to excuse it.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: At first I did adore a twinkling Starre,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But now I worship a celestiall Sunne:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Vn‑heedfull vowes may heedfully be broken,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And he wants wit, that wants resolued will,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To learne his wit, t'exchange the bad for better;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Fie, fie, vnreuerend tongue, to call her bad,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Whose soueraignty so oft thou hast preferd,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: With twenty thousand soule‑confirming oathes,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I cannot leaue to loue; and yet I doe:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But there I leaue to loue, where I should loue.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: {% italic: Iulia %} I loose, and {% italic: Valentine %} I loose,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: If I keepe them, I needs must loose my selfe:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: If I loose them, thus finde I by their losse,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For {% italic: Valentine, %} my selfe: for {% italic: Iulia, Siluia. %}

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I to my selfe am deerer then a friend,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For Loue is still most precious in it selfe,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And {% italic: Siluia %} (witnesse heauen that made her faire)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Shewes {% italic: Iulia %} but a swarthy Ethiope.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I will forget that {% italic: Iulia %} is aliue,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Remembring that my Loue to her is dead.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And {% italic: Valentine %} Ile hold an Enemie,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Ayming at {% italic: Siluia %} as a sweeter friend.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I cannot now proue constant to my selfe,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Without some treachery vs'd to {% italic: Valentine. %}

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: This night he meaneth with a Corded‑ladder

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To climbe celestiall {% italic: Siluia's %} chamber window,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: My selfe in counsaile his competitor.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Now presently Ile giue her father notice

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Of their disguising and pretended flight:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Who (all inrag'd) will banish {% italic: Valentine: %}

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For {% italic: Thurio %} he intends shall wed his daughter,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But {% italic: Valentine %} being gon, Ile quickely crosse

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: By some slie tricke, blunt {% italic: Thurio's %} dull proceeding.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: {% italic: Loue %} lend me wings, to make my purpose swift

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: At thou hast lent me wit, to plot this drift.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Counsaile, {% italic: Lucetta %}, gentle girle assist me,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And eu'n in kinde loue, I doe coniure thee,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Who art the Table wherein all my thoughts

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Are visibly Character'd, and engrau'd,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To lesson me, and tell me some good meane

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: How with my honour I may vndertake

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: A iourney to my louing {% italic: Protheus %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Alas, the way is wearisome and long.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: A true‑deuoted Pilgrime is not weary

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To measure Kingdomes with his feeble steps,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Much lesse shall the that hath Loues wings to flie,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And when the flight is made to one so deere,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Of such diuine perfection as Sir {% italic: Protheus %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Better forbeare, till {% italic: Protheus %} make returne.

lines.speaker: Iul:
lines.text: Oh, know'st y u not, his looks are my foules food?

lines.speaker: Iul:
lines.text: Pitty the dearth that I haue pined in,

lines.speaker: Iul:
lines.text: By longing for that food so long a time.

lines.speaker: Iul:
lines.text: Didst thou but know the inly touch of Loue,

lines.speaker: Iul:
lines.text: Thou wouldst as soone goe kindle fire with snow

lines.speaker: Iul:
lines.text: As seeke to quench the fire of Loue with words.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: I doe not seeke to quench your Loues hot fire,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: But qualifie the fires extreame rage,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Lest it should burne aboue the bounds of reason.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: The more thou dam'st it vp, the more it burnes:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: The Current that with gentle murmure glides

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: (Thou know'st) being stop'd, impatiently doth rage:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: But when his faire course is not hindered,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: He makes sweet musicke with th'enameld stones,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Giuing a gentle kisse to euery sedge

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: He ouer‑taketh in his pilgrimage.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And so by many winding nookes he straies

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: With willing sport to the wilde Ocean.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Then let me goe, and hinder not my course:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Ile be as patient as a gentle streame,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And make a pastime of each weary step,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Till the last step haue brought me to my Loue,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And there Ile rest, as after much turmoile

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: A blessed soule doth in {% italic: Elizium %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: But in what habit will you goe along?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Not like a woman, for I would preuent

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: The loose encounters of lasciuious men:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Gentle {% italic: Lucetta, %} fit me with such weedes

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: As may beseeme some well reputed Page.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Why then your Ladiship must cut your haire.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: No girle, Ile knit it vp in silken strings,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: With twentie od‑conceited true‑loue knots:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To be fantastique, may become a youth

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Of greater time then I shall shew to be.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: What fashion (Madam) shall I make your bree­ ( ches?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: That fits as well, as tell me (good my Lord)

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: What compasse will you weare your Farthingale?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Why eu'n what fashion thou best likes ( {% italic: Lucetta. %})

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: You must needs haue with a cod‑peece (Ma­ ( dam)

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Out, out, ( {% italic: Lucetta %}) that wilbe illfauourd.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: A round hose (Madam) now's not worth a pin

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Vnlesse you haue a cod‑peece to stick pins on.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: {% italic: Lucetta %}, as thou lou'st me let me haue

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: What thou think'st meet, and is most mannerly.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: But tell me (wench) how will the world repute me

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: For vndertaking s? vnstaid a iourney?

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: I feare me it will make me scandaliz'd.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: If you thinke so, then stay at home, and go not.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Nay, that I will not.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Then neuer dreame on Infamy, but go:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: If {% italic: Protheus %} like your iourney, when you come,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: No matter who's displeas'd, when you are gone:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: I feare me he will scarce be pleas'd with all.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: That is the least ( {% italic: Lucetta %}) of my feare:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: A thousand oathes, an Ocean of his teares,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And instances of infinite of Loue,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Warrant me welcome to my {% italic: Protheus %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: All these are seruants to deceitfull men.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Base men, that vse them to so base effect;

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: But truer starres did gouerne {% italic: Protheus %} birth,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: His words are bonds, his oathes are oracles,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: His loue sincere, his thoughts immaculate,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: His teares, pure messengers, sent from his heart,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: His heary as far from fraud, as heauen from earth.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Pray heau'n he proue so when you come to him.

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Now, as thou lou'st me, do him not that wrong,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To beare a hard opinion of his truth:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Onely deserue my loue, by louing him,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: And presently goe with me to my chamber

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To take a note of what I stand in need of,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: To furnish me vpon my longing iourney:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: All that is mine I leaue at thy dispose,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: My goods, my Lands, my reputation,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Onely, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence:

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: Come; answere not: but to it presently,

lines.speaker: Iul.
lines.text: I am impatient of my tarriance.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Thurio %}, giue vs leaue (I pray) a while,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: We haue some secrets to confer about.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Now tell me {% italic: Protheus, %} what's your will with me?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: My gracious Lord, that which I wold discouer,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: The Law of friendship bids me to conceale,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But when I call to minde your gracious fauours

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Done to me (vndeseruing as I am)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: My dutie pricks me on to vtter that

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Which else, no worldly good should draw from me:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Know (worthy Prince) Sir {% italic: Valentine %} my friend

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: This night intends to steale away your daughter:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: My selfe am one made priuy to the plot.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I know you haue determin'd to bestow her

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: On {% italic: Thurio, %} whom your gentle daughter hates,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And should she thus be stolne away from you,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: It would be much vexation to your age.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Thus (for my duties sake) I rather chose

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: To crosse my friend in his intended drift,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Then (by concealing it) heap on your head

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: A pack of sorrowes, which would presse you downe

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: (Being vnpreuented) to your timelesse graue.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: {% italic: Protheus, %} I thank thee for thine honest care,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Which to requite, command me while I liue.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: This loue of theirs, my selfe haue often seene,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Haply when they haue iudg'd me fast asleepe,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And oftentimes haue purpos'd to forbid

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Ualentine %} her companie, and my Court.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: But fearing lest my iealous ayme might erre,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And so (vnworthily) disgrace the man

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: (A rashnesse that I euer yet haue shun'd)

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I gaue him gentle lookes, thereby to finde

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: That which thy selfe hast now disclos'd to me.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And that thou maist perceiue my feare of this,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Knowing that tender youth is soone suggested,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I nightly lodge her in an vpper Towre,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: The key whereof, my selfe haue euer kept:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And thence she cannot be conuay'd away.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Know (noble Lord) they haue deuis'd a meane

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: How he her chamber‑window will ascend,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And with a Corded‑ladder fetch her downe:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For which, the youthfull Louer now is gone,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And this way comes he with it presently.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Where (if it please you) you may intercept him.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But (good my Lord) doe it so cunningly

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That my discouery be not aimed at:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For, loue of you, not hate vnto my friend,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Vpon mine Honor, he shall neuer know

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: That I had any light from thee of this.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Adiew, my Lord, Sir {% italic: Valentine %} is comming.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Valentine, %} whether away so fast?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Please it your Grace, there is a Messenger

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: That stayes to beare my Letters to my friends,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And I am going to deliuer them.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Be they of much import?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: The tenure of them doth but signifie

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: My health, and happy being at your Court.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Nay then no matter: stay with me a while,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I am to breake with thee of some affaires

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: That touch me neere: wherein thou must be secret.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: 'Tis not vnknown to thee, that I haue sought

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: To match my friend Sir {% italic: Thurio %}, to my daughter.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I know it well (my Lord) and sure the Match

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Were rich and honourable: besides, the gentleman

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Is full of Vertue, Bounty, Worth, and Qualities

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Beseeming such a Wife, as your faire daughter:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Cannot your Grace win her to fancie him?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: No, trust me, She is peeuish, sullen, froward,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Prowd, disobedient, stubborne, lacking duty,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Neither regarding that she is my childe,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Nor fearing me, as if I were her father:

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And may I say to thee, this pride of hers

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: (Vpon aduice) hath drawne my loue from her,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And where I thought the remnant of mine age

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Should haue beene cherish'd by her child‑like dutie,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I now am full resolu'd to take a wife,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And turne her out, to who will take her in:

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Then let her beauty be her wedding dowre:

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: For me, and my possessions she esteemes not.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: What would your Grace haue me to do in this?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: There is a Lady in {% italic: Verona %} heere

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Whom I affect: but she is nice, and coy,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And naught esteemes my aged eloquence.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Now therefore would I haue thee to my Tutor

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: (For long agone I haue forgot to court,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Besides the fashion of the time is chang'd)

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: How, and which way I may bestow my selfe

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: To be regarded in her sun‑bright eye.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Win her with gifts, if she respest not words,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Dumbe Iewels often in their silent kinde

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: More then quicke words, doe moue a womans minde.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: But she did scorne a present that I sent her,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: A woman somtime scorns what best her.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Send her another: neuer giue her ore,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: For scorne at first, makes after‑loue the more.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: If she doe frowne, ' is not in hate of you,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: But rather to beget more loue in you.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: If she doe chide, 'tis not to haue you gone,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: For why, the fooles are mad, if left alone.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Take no repulse, what euer she doth say,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: For, get you gon, she doth not meane away.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Flatter, and praise, commend, extoll their graces:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Though nere so blacke, say they haue Angells faces,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: That man that hath a tongue, I say is no man,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: But she I meane, is promis'd by her friends

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Vnto a youthfull Gentleman of worth,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And kept seuerely from resort of men,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: That no man hath accesse by day to her.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Why then I would resort to her by night.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I, but the doores be lockt, and keyes kept safe,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: That no man hath recourse to her by night.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: What letts but one may enter at her window?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And built so sheluing, that one cannot climbe it

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Without apparant hazard of his life.

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Why then a Ladder quaintly made of Cords

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: To cast vp, with a paire of anchoring hookes,

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Would serue to scale another {% italic: Hero's %} towre,

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: So bold {% italic: Leander %} would aduenture it.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Now as thou art a Gentleman of blood

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Aduise me, where I may haue such a Ladder.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: When would you vse it? pray sir, tell me that.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: This very night; for Loue is like a childe

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: That longs for euery thing that he can come by.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: By seauen a clock, ile get you such a Ladder.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: But harke thee: I will goe to her alone,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: How shall I best conuey the Ladder thither?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: It will be light (my Lord) that you may beare it

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Vnder a cloake, that is of any length.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: A cloake as long as thine will serue the turne?

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: I my good Lord.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Then let me see thy cloake,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Ile get me one of such another length.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Why any cloake will serue the turn (my Lord)

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: How shall I fashion me to weare a cloake?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I pray thee let me feele thy cloake vpon me.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: What Letter is this same? what's here? to {% italic: Siluia %}?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And heere an Engine fit for my proceeding,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Ile be so bold to breake the scale for once.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: My thoughts do harbour with my {% italic: Siluia %} nightly,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And slaues they are to me, that send them flying.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Oh, could their Master come, and goe as lightly,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Himselfe would lodge where (senceles) they are lying.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: My Herald Thoughts, in thy pure bosome rest‑them,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: While I (their King) that thither them importune

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Doe curse the grace, that with such grace hath blest them,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Because my selfe doe want my seruants fortune.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I curse my selfe, for they are sent by me,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: That they should harbour where their Lord should be.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: What's here? {% italic: Siluia, this night 1 will enfranchise thee. %}

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: 'Tis so: and heere's the Ladder for the purpose.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Why {% italic: Phaeton %} (for thou art {% italic: Merops %} sonne)

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Wilt thou aspire to guide the heauenly Car?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And with thy daring folly burne the world?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Wilt thou reach stars, bccause they shine on thee?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Goe base Intruder, ouer‑weening Slaue,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Bestow thy fawning smiles on equall mates,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And thinke my patience, (more then thy desert)

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Is priuiledge for thy departure hence.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Thanke me for this, more then for all the fauors

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Which (all too‑much) I haue bestowed on thee.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: But if thou linger in my Territories

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Longer then swiftest expedition

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Will giue thee time to leaue our royall Court,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: By heauen, my wrath shall farre exceed the loue

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: I euer bore my daughter, or thy selfe.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Be gone, I will not heare thy vaine excuse,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: But as thou lou'st thy life, make speed from hence.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And why not death, rather then liuing torment?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: To die, is to be banisht from my selfe,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And {% italic: Siluia %} is my selfe: banish'd from her

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Is selfe from selfe. A deadly banishment:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: What light, is light, if {% italic: Siluia %} be not seene?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: What ioy is ioy, if {% italic: Siluia %} be not by?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Vnlesse it be to thinke that she is by

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And feed vpon the shadow of perfection.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Except I be by {% italic: Siluia %} in the night,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: There is no musicke in the Nightingale.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Vnlesse I looke on {% italic: Siluia %} in the day,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: There is no day for me to looke vpon.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Shee is my essence, and I leaue to be;

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: If I be not by her faire influence

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Foster'd, illumin'd, cherish'd, kept aliue.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I flie not death, to flie his deadly doome,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Tarry I heere, I but attend on death,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: But flie I hence, I flie away from life.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Run (boy) run, run, and seeke him out.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: So‑hough, Soa hough⸺

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: What seest thou?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Him we goe to finde,

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: There's not a haire on's head, but t'is a {% italic: Valentine. %}

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: {% italic: Valentine %}?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Who then? his Spirit?

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Neither,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: What then?

lines.speaker: Ual.
lines.text: Nothing.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Can nothing speake? Master, shall I strike?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Who wouldst thou strike?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Nothing.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Villaine, forbeare.

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Why Sir, Ile strike nothing: I pray you.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Sirha, I say forbeare: friend {% italic: Valentine, %} a word.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: My eares are stopt, cannot hear good newes,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: So much of bad already hath possest them.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Then in dumbe silence will I bury mine,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: For they are harsh, vn‑tuneable, and bad.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Is {% italic: Siluia %} dead?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: No, {% italic: Valentine. %}

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: No {% italic: Valentine %} indeed, for sacred {% italic: Siluia, %}

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Hath she forsworne me?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: No, {% italic: Ualentine. %}

lines.speaker: Vel.
lines.text: No {% italic: Valentine, %} if {% italic: Siluia %} haue forsworne me.

lines.speaker: Vel.
lines.text: What is your newes?

lines.speaker: Lau.
lines.text: Sir, there is a proclamation, y t you are vanished.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That thou art banish'd: oh that's the newes,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: From hence, from {% italic: Siluia %}, and from me thy friend.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Oh, I haue fed vpon this woe already,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: And now excesse of it will make me surfet.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Doth {% italic: Siluia %} know that I am banish'd?

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: I, I: and she hath offered to the doome

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: (Which vn‑reuerst stands in effectuall force)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: A Sea of melting pearle, which some call teares;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Thoseat her fathers churlish feete she tenderd,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: With them vpon her knees, her humble selfe,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Wringing her hands, whose whitenes so became them,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: As if but now they waxed pale for woe:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But neither bended knees, pure hands held vp,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Sad sighes, deepe grones, nor siluer‑shedding teares

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Could penetrate her vncompassionate Sire;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: But {% italic: Valentine, %} if he be tane, must die.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Besides, her intercession chaf'd him so,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: When she for thy repeale was suppliant,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: That to close prison he commanded her,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: With many bitter threats of biding there.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: No more: vnles the next word that thou speak'st

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: Haue some malignant power vpon my life:

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: If so: I pray thee breath it in mine eare,

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: As ending Antheme of my endlesse dolor.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Cease to lament for that thou canst not helpe,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And study helpe for that which thou lament'st,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Time is the Nurse, and breeder of all good;

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Here, if thou stay, thou canst not see thy loue:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Hope is a louers staffe, walke hence with that

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And manage it, against despairing thoughts:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Which, being writ to me, shall be deliuer'd

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Euen in the milke‑white bosome of thy Loue.

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: The time now serues not to expostulate,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Come, Ile conuey thee through the City‑gate,

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: And ere I part with thee, confer at large

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Of all that may concerne thy Loue‑affaires:

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: As thou lou'st {% italic: Siluia %} (though not for thy selfe)

lines.speaker: Pro.
lines.text: Regard thy danger, and along with me.

lines.speaker: Val.
lines.text: I pray thee {% italic: Launce %}, and if thou seest my Boy

lines.speaker: Val.
